body:
<!--

If it is a bug report:
- make sure you are able to repro it on the latest released version. 
You can install the latest version from https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](../docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](../docs/KNOWNISSUES.md).
- Fill out the following repro template

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.
-->
## Steps to reproduce

`chsh -s /usr/bin/powershell`
## Expected behavior

should be able to change the shell to powershell
## Actual behavior

it says `/usr/bin/powershell is an invalid shell`
## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

``` powershell
> $PSVersionTable
alpha.9

```

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: I suggest that the package should add PowerShell as a Shell and remove it when it is removed.

comments.author: mmckinst
comments.body:
needs to have --after-install and --after-remove options added at https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/33fcdf37e558e9e9a7800b01a083e65f4127d7fd/build.psm1#L1082-L1102 for this with a shell script like below:

```
# after-install
if ! [ -f /etc/shells ] || ! grep -q '^/usr/bin/powershell$' /etc/shells; then
  echo '/usr/bin/powershell' >> /etc/shells
fi

# after-remove
sed -i '\!^/usr/bin/powershell$!d' /etc/shells
```

comments.author: jldeen
comments.body:
Just tested on Ubuntu 14.04.05 and was able to chsh by first adding the path /opt/microsoft/powershell/6.0.0-alpha.9/powershell to /etc/shells 

Then I typed sudo chsh -s /opt/microsoft/powershell/6.0.0-alpha.9/powershell. Note: I received the following errors, but still seemed to work. 

sent invalidate(passwd) request, exiting
sent invalidate(group) request, exiting
sent invalidate(passwd) request, exiting

I then changed the shell back by typing chsh -s /bin/bash

title: cannot chsh to powershell without editing /etc/shells
